awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Transgene Expression and Retention by Co-delivery of DNA Vectors with Modified Histones
awd_abstract_narration:
Gene therapy has been offered as a potential cure for a wide range of diseases, including hemophilia, cystic fibrosis, Parkinson's, HIV, hepatitis, and heart disease. Conventional gene delivery approaches currently lack the safety, efficiency and durability required for many research, industrial and/or clinical applications. Understanding how to create and maintain active gene expression will have broad-ranging impacts on gene delivery and expression in humans. The proposed work will bring effective gene therapies closer to reality, and will also train and inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers through their active participation in this interdisciplinary research.

The long-term objective of this project is to elucidate how long-term cellular memories of transcriptional states are created and maintained to advance research, industrial and gene therapy applications requiring regulated transgene expression. The specific scientific objectives are to 1) develop a robust strategy for co-delivering transgenes together with modified histone proteins promoting active transcription; and 2) evaluate and enhance protein expression from chromatin assembled on transgenic DNA. The established delivery approach is expected to significantly improve the uptake and controlled expression of transgenic DNA and to be compatible with a broad range of vectors. The fundamental kowledge gained regarding the design of epigenetic systems for heterologous gene expression could have profound implications for all eukaryotic gene expression systems. Such insight could, for example, significantly expand the scope and efficacy of human gene therapy, leading to cures for many serious diseases.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this proposal is to improve the transcription efficiency of transgenes by co-delivering modified histones with therapeutic gene vectors. During the cause of the project, we have developed a robust co-delivery approach of transgenic DNA with modified histones. The introduced histone modifications, including lysine acetylation and lysine methylation mimics, do not significantly alter chromatin compactness particularly at a modest protein to DNA ratio. We subsequently assessed the efficacy of modified histones in altering the transfection and retention efficiency of transgene. Our results suggest that co-delivery of histone octamers with transgene can result in short-term loss of transfection efficiency. The transgene, however, was retained with better efficiency in cells. Selected histone modifications working as transcriptional activation markers can improve transfection efficiency compared to those transfected with wild-type histones. Collectively, our results suggest that presetting the epigenetic state of transgene does not improve short-term transfection efficiency but facilitate long-term maintenance of transfected transgene. Although our findings do not support the central hypothesis that co-delivery of transgene and histones can improve transfection efficiency, the results verified the role of histones in facilitating DNA stability both in culture medium and post-transfection into cells. The exogenously introduced histone modifications, such as H3K9,14Q and H4K16Q, can serve as the anchor point for recruiting an active transcriptional complex, and facilitate the initiation of transcription rending higher transcription efficiency.

The project has provided interdisciplinary training opportunities on bioengineering and biochemistry for 5 undergraduate and 4 graduate students, including one African American student. Two of the participating undergraduate students have chosen to pursue graduate studies in the STEM area. Major results of the project have been presented in conferences and disseminated via peer-reviewed scientific journals.


Last Modified: 05/24/2023
Modified by: Chongli Yuan
